sen.j: 相馬事件（そうまじけん）とは、明治年間に起こった御家騒動の一つ。
sen.e: Soma Jiken is one of family troubles which occurred during the Meiji period.
Some Jiken is one of the family troubles occurred in the Meiji period in Japan.

sen.j: 精神病患者への処遇や、新興新聞によるセンセーショナルな報道の是非を巡り、世間へ大きな影響を与えた。
sen.e: Soma Jiken created great controversy to the world, which included treatment of mental patients and sensational reports by emerging papers among others.
The incident had a tremendous impact on the society, by raising controversy over treatment to mental patients and sensational reporting by newspapers that had emerged at the time.

sen.j: 旧相馬中村藩主、相馬誠胤（そうまともたね）の統合失調症（推定）の症状が悪化。
sen.e: SOMA Tomotane, governor of ex-domain of Soma-nakamura, had been suffering from loss of coordination disorder, which became worse.
Tomotane SOMA, the former lord of the Soma-Nakaura Domain, was suffering mental disorder, reputedly schizophrenic, and the condition got worse.

sen.e: Tomotane SOMA, the former lord of the Soma-Nakaura Domain, was suffering mental disorder, reputedly schizophrenic, and the condition got worse.

sen.j: 1879年に家族が宮内省に自宅監禁を申し入れ、以後自宅で監禁、後に癲狂院（現在の精神科に相当）へ入院。
sen.e: In 1879, Soma family filed a request to the Ministry of Imperial to put Tomotane under confinement, which was admitted, but later Tomotane was hospitalized to a mental clinic.

In 1879, the Soma family reported to the Imperial Household Ministry to take Tomotane under custody, and did so for awhile, but eventually Tomotane was hospitalized to the Tenkyoin, a mental clinic of the time.

sen.j: 1883年、旧藩士の錦織剛清（にしごりたけきよ）が主君の病状に疑いを持ち、家族による不当監禁であるとして家令・志賀直道（志賀直哉の祖父）ら関係者を告発したことから事件が表面化した。
sen.e: In 1883, former feudal samurai Takekiyo NISHIGORI doubted about conditions of his lord, and accused the persons concerned, including butler Naomichi SHIGA who was grandfather of Naoya SHIGA that the confinement by the family is inappropriate.

This was revealed to the public in 1883 when Takekiyo NISHIGORI, a former member of the Soma Domain, started to doubt the condition of his former master and accused the persons concerned, including Naomichi SHIGA, the steward to the family (grandfather of Naoya SHIGA, a famous novelist), of inappropriate custody.

sen.e: At that time, diagnosis of mental illness was still immature, and even prominent university professors could reach inconsistent results.

sen.e: In 1887, NISHIGORI sneaked into the mental clinic of the Tokyo-fu (Tokyo Prefecture) where Soma was hospitalized.

sen.e: NISHIGORI succeeded to seize Tomotane, but was arrested in a week.
NISHIGORI succeeded in getting Tomotane back, but was arrested in a week.

sen.j: 錦織は、家宅侵入罪に問われ禁固処分を受けるとともに、偏執的な行動が批判を受ける。
sen.e: NISHIGORI was accused of unlawful entry and was punished by imprisonment without work, and the public criticized his actions as paranoia.

sen.j: 法制度への影響
sen.e: Influences to legislation
Impact on the legislative system
Impact on the legislative system

sen.j: 相馬事件がきっかけとなり、精神病者の監護（監禁および保護）の手続きについて問題意識が高まり、1900年に精神病者監護法が制定された。
sen.e: After the Soma Jiken, social concerns on proceedings of confinement and protection of those mentally suffering rose, and in 1900, a law was enacted on confinement and protection of mental patients.
On the back of the incident, general concerns on how to treat people with mental illness, particularly on custody and protection, increased only to establish the Mental Patient Custody Act in 1900.
sen.cmt: 精神病者監護法 Mental Patient Custody Act としました。
sen.e: On the back of the incident, general concerns on how to treat people with mental illness, particularly on custody and protection, increased only to establish the Mental Patient Custody Act in 1900.

sen.j: これは精神病者の人権保護や治療を目的とするものではなく、精神病院（精神病室）および私宅（神社仏閣における参籠所や公私立の精神病者収容施設なども「私宅」のカテゴリーに含まれる場合もあった）における監置を法によって規定するといった隔離を主眼にするものであった。
sen.e: The law was made not for the purpose of human rights protection or for treatment of mental patients, but for isolations by determining confinement and protection of those patients in hospitals or at private residences, including guest houses of shrines or temples and private or public accommodations for mental patients.

The law was made not for the purpose of human rights protection or for treatment of mental patients, rather for isolating the patients, by settling a rule to place them either in hospitals specialized for mental patients, or at private residents (guest houses of shrines or temples, and private or public accommodations for mental patients are categorized as "private resident" in some cases).
